[{'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-21 01:17:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-21 07:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-21 08:51:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-21 09:45:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This seems like a good way to do this kind of thing. My main concern would be if there were a situation where for some reason there were many tens of thousands of resource providers that needed the update. As I understand it, we're not expecting that, right?"}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-22 02:32:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> As I understand it, we're not expecting that, right?

That's my understanding, too. Since we already have the migration script[1] in Rocky, this applies to *some* of the existing providers that unfortunately didn't go through the migration path in Rocky.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/377138/62/nova/objects/resource_provider.py@917"}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-26 06:27:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

I'm not sure how we migrate to this new placement's alembic management scheme after the "nova_api->placement DB migration" has been done.
That said, `placement-manage db sync` just after Dan's migration script [1] fails at least my local environment.

    $ placement-manage db sync
    INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Context impl MySQLImpl.
    INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Will assume non-transactional DDL.
    INFO  [alembic.runtime.migration] Running upgrade  -> b4ed3a175331, Initial 
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/local/bin/placement-manage", line 10, in <module>
        sys.exit(main())
      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/placement/cmd/manage.py", line 82, in main
        return_code = func()
      File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/placement/cmd/manage.py", line 31, in db_sync
        migration.upgrade('head')
        
    ------------snip----------------
    
    oslo_db.exception.DBError: (pymysql.err.InternalError) (1050, u"Table 'allocations' already exists") [SQL: u'\nCREATE TABLE allocations (\n\tcreated_at DATETIME, \n\tupdated_at DATETIME, \n\tid INTEGER NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, \n\tresource_provider_id INTEGER NOT NULL, \n\tconsumer_id VARCHAR(36) NOT NULL, \n\tresource_class_id INTEGER NOT NULL, \n\tused INTEGER NOT NULL, \n\tPRIMARY KEY (id)\n)\n\n'] (Background on this error at: http://sqlalche.me/e/2j85)

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/603234/8/tools/mysql-migrate-db.sh

-W this until it is clarified.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-26 10:13:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Excellent catch tetsuro. I think what we probably need is for the end of the migration script to call 'stamp'[1] in alembic. This should have the effect of saying "I'm already at that version." At which point your migration can run happily when the next sync is called.

I would guess that the best way to do this would be to expose a 'placement-manage db stamp <version>' command, so that Dan's script can call that at the end of itself. Where version is b4ed3a175331 . The link below gives some guidance on how to do that.

Do you want to do that Tetsuro or should I?


[1] https://alembic.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/api/commands.html#alembic.command.stamp'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-26 14:12:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I would guess that the best way to do this would be to expose a 'placement-manage db stamp <version>'

Yes, I take this. I'll look into it."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-26 14:14:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> This seems like a good way to do this kind of thing. My main concern would be if there were a situation where for some reason there were many tens of thousands of resource providers that needed the update. As I understand it, we're not expecting that, right?

This was also my concern, since we stopped doing data migrations within schema migrations like this years ago since it impacts downtime. That said, I assume the single statement select/update here is faster than adding an online data migration CLI hook/method for this in python anyway - the only difference is you can run the hook method at any point while services are running and it won't affect your downtime while running the sync."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-27 14:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Can we rebase this on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/617565/ so we actually get grenade/tempest runs with it?'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-28 08:04:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-11-28 13:36:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

> Can we rebase this on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/617565/ so we actually get grenade/tempest runs with it?

Done. But, yes, it still passes the tests.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-11-28 23:51:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > This seems like a good way to do this kind of thing. My main
 > concern would be if there were a situation where for some reason
 > there were many tens of thousands of resource providers that needed
 > the update. As I understand it, we're not expecting that, right?
 > 
 > This was also my concern, since we stopped doing data migrations
 > within schema migrations like this years ago since it impacts
 > downtime. That said, I assume the single statement select/update
 > here is faster than adding an online data migration CLI hook/method
 > for this in python anyway

Yes.

 >  - the only difference is you can run the
 > hook method at any point while services are running and it won't
 > affect your downtime while running the sync.

Not really. There will still be "downtime" -- due to locks being taken on the records in question. It's just our "online" data migrations do the operations on smaller batches of records -- which is inconsequential unless the database has a huge number of records.

Doing an `UPDATE resource_providers SET root_provider_id = id WHERE root_provider_id IS NULL` would have been the simplest and fastest approach to this data migration, even for a table with a million provider records. But, we have a rule, and we follow that rule for everything.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-12-03 14:03:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-12-03 14:20:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Okay, I've understood why we didn't have this kind of migration. But speaking about the Stein release we can't avoid having some downtime because of the nova->placement DB migration, anyway.
Can't we think this is a part of that migration rather than within-placement DB migration?
Otherwise, we can’t say “we are sure all the root ids in the DB have some value” forever, which means we can’t clean up the TODOs forever, which we want to avoid. I mean, the Stein release is the only good opportunity, isn’t it?"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-12-03 15:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Tetsuro, traditionally what we have done is create a patch series, the last patch in the series is called a "blocker migration" patch.

Essentially, it's a patch series that includes some online data migration in the `nova-manage online_data_migrate` collection and a check that there are no more data records that exist in the old, pre-migration state (in this case, the check would be for any records that have a NULL root_provider_id).

After the "block migration" patch is merged, then TODOs can be cleaned up accordingly.

Best,
-jay'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-12-03 18:17:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Doing an `UPDATE resource_providers SET root_provider_id = id WHERE
 > root_provider_id IS NULL` would have been the simplest and fastest
 > approach to this data migration, even for a table with a million
 > provider records. But, we have a rule, and we follow that rule for
 > everything.

I'm confused Jay. You seem to be saying "what you have here is the simplest solution" but also saying "don't do that simplest thing".

If we already know that somebody has to do 'placement-manage db sync' during an upgrade to do schema migrations, why not do a data migration there too? It sounds like you saying "because those are the rules". If that's the case, why are those the rules?'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-12-04 10:19:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Unless we can come up with a reason other than "that's the rules in nova" for not doing things this way, I think we should do things this way. It is simple, contained, efficient.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-12-04 15:29:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

> Unless we can come up with a reason other than "that's the rules in
 > nova" for not doing things this way, I think we should do things
 > this way. It is simple, contained, efficient.

IMHO, the reason is to avoid having one in-schema data migration in the history here just because we think it's co-located with a service migration, if in the future we're going to do online migrations of data. I certainly hope that placement is not going to move (backwards) to having schema migrations that cannot be applied to a running service and that manipulate data in place. Such a move puts placement in a blocking position for all services that depend on it, and I'm definitely not in favor of doing that.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-12-04 15:48:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> IMHO, the reason is to avoid having one in-schema data migration in
 > the history here just because we think it's co-located with a
 > service migration, if in the future we're going to do online
 > migrations of data. I certainly hope that placement is not going to
 > move (backwards) to having schema migrations that cannot be applied
 > to a running service and that manipulate data in place. Such a move
 > puts placement in a blocking position for all services that depend
 > on it, and I'm definitely not in favor of doing that.

I feel like I'm missing some critical piece of the puzzle because I  still don't get it. Can you describe a more concrete scenario that "puts placement in a blocking position for all services"?

I feel like we've done that over and over again with the API (in the relationship with nova and placement) so I think you must mean something different, an example might make it more clear.

To be clear: I'm not trying to say "let's just change stuff, changing stuff is cool, woot". It's just that this thing that tetsuro has done is fast and seemingly safe, at least in isolation. A useful tool and method.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-12-04 17:15:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I feel like I'm missing some critical piece of the puzzle because I
 >  still don't get it. Can you describe a more concrete scenario that
 > "puts placement in a blocking position for all services"?

It's a common pattern for upgrades today for me to apply the schema changes from stein to my rocky deployment on Wednesday and upgrade my code on Saturday. I do that to minimize the amount of downtime I have during my scheduled outage window on the weekend, by doing whatever I can before that while things are running, which makes the outage just "push out new code and restart services together" while the API is down.

If the data is manipulated by the schema migrations, then I have to do both of those things together, because if I don't, the data at the time of the schema migration will be migrated, but anything added between Wednesday and Saturday will not be patched up. Further, what tends to happen is that either (a) schema migrations that expect to migrate all the data also add constraints when they're done, which would be incompatible with current code or (b) new code assumes that all data has been migrated because the schema migrations did it. IME, it's difficult to test (b) completely without hackery because you have to apply schema migrations and then somehow force old-style data back into the DB to test if the new code can handle it.

If you watch the talk I did in Berlin with CERN, you'll see they specifically called out that they applied their schema updates well in advance of a very quick outage window moving from queens to rocky, which helped them keep downtime at a historical low (compared to the one-shot approach in cellsv1).

 > To be clear: I'm not trying to say "let's just change stuff,
 > changing stuff is cool, woot". It's just that this thing that
 > tetsuro has done is fast and seemingly safe, at least in isolation.

Yep, and it's a very straightforward/common procedure. It's also the exact thing that operators were asking us to stop doing in 2013 because their upgrades were requiring lots of downtime, specifically because of data migrations in schema changes. One change in isolation isn't usually a big deal, but you string several together with a large database and it becomes a problem.

If you're using a deployment that does upgrades of the whole control plane at once, then any of the things that any service has to do offline during the upgrade ends up blocking everything else. If all the services can do a quick code bump, return to online state and then continue doing lazy data fixups, then the amount of time that the API(s) have to be down is minimized. If, however, one service has a four hour process that needs to happen during its upgrade, then even if the other services can be quick, their APIs are down as well until the whole controller is ready. Obviously what is proposed here is not a four hour thing on probably any database, and obviously the unified controller upgrade isn't the most awesome way to do it. However, it is a very common reality at the moment. Thus, whatever we can to do avoid placement contributing to that level of downtime, the better, IMHO.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-12-04 17:28:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

This is a straight forward-only, entirely backwards-compatible and quick operation even on a huge set of providers. I understand your concerns Dan but I believe a blanket approach of always requiring any data migration to be done in a batched manner (note I didn't say "online" because both of these approaches are online...) is a practical approach.

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-12-04 17:55:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> This is a straight forward-only, entirely backwards-compatible and
 > quick operation even on a huge set of providers.

In trying to explain why this isn't enough, I realize I may have missed one detail. This patch is actually the data migration to fix up any rows that haven't been fixed already by something that happens on-demand in the previous release, is that right? If so, that makes some of my explanation earlier not as relevant. However, I still don't think that the data manipulation should be inter-mixed with the schema changes, as it only takes skipping one release in an FFU fashion here to get yourself into the same problem of applying this and it having to re-write every row before the next should-be-transparent schema change can run.

 > I understand your
 > concerns Dan but I believe a blanket approach of always requiring
 > any data migration to be done in a batched manner (note I didn't
 > say "online" because both of these approaches are online...) is a
 > practical approach.

Batching doesn't really have anything to do with it. It reduces the linear time that the table has to be locked in order to make these changes, but in cases where we know a single operation is fast for large tables, that's fine. If this were in nova, I'd be totally fine with an online migration handler that just did the sql query to fix the whole thing in one shot if that works better. What I'm not okay with is mixing the two tasks, both for the operational reasons as well as confusing the next person who comes along to make a data-migration-needing change and not understanding why some schema migrations can do that and some can't.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-12-04 18:04:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Also, FWIW, neutron moved to doing migrationy things this way a while ago using purely alembic machinery to accomplish the same thing. So if it makes you feel better to not have to implement a new tool or hook in a tool, there is this:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/neutron-specs/specs/liberty/online-schema-migrations.html'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-12-05 17:37:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@Dan
Thank you for the detail explanation. IIUC, what needs to be done is to separate "expansive migrations" and "contract migrations" so that operators can do those migrations one by one, and after that, this patch can be landed on as a "contract migration", right?

I think we can leave the existing `db sync` command as an operation to process those migrations in one time. If this understanding is right and is okay with us in the room, I look into that.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-12-21 01:47:12.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'd like to abandon this once in favor of
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/624943/.

I brought this discussion in the ML. Hope that you're interested. Thanks.
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/001114.html"}]

commit_message:
Set root_provider_id in the database

When nested resource provider feature was added in Rocky,
root_provider_id column, which should be non-None value, is created in
the resource provider DB.

However, online data migration is only done implicitly via listing or
showing resource providers. This patch provides via alembic a migration
script to make sure all the resource providers are ready for nested
provider feature, that is, all the root_provider_ids in the DB have now
non-None value.

Change-Id: I15192583bcd4aaf121c155283cb627fe4875efb6
Related-Bug:#1803925

Update author-email in setup.cfg

the openstack-discuss mailing list (*).

the openstack-discuss mailing list in setup.cfg.

'}, {'created': '2018-12-20 00:47:11.000000000', 'message': 'Download, and install elasticsearch server for freezer-api

In devstack/pkg, there is an elasticsearch.sh for downloading,
installing, starting and uninstalling of elasticsearch server,
but it is not flexible. In the future, freezer-api needs to support
ubuntu-xenial and ubuntu-bonic, which requires different elasticsearch
server versions. In addition, the programming interface of elastic
search server varies greatly before and after 5.0.0, which requires
different code of freezer-api to support. Pre-5.0.0 version
of elasticsearch server cannot be installed on ubuntu-bonic.
For the convenience of modification, freezer-api maintains
the elastic search.sh script by itself.

Change-Id: Ie069e2fd1e29daf53d8b1490f152cd820df036fe
'}]
commit_message:
Download, and install elasticsearch server for freezer-api

In devstack/pkg, there is an elasticsearch.sh for downloading,
installing, starting and uninstalling of elasticsearch server,
but it is not flexible. In the future, freezer-api needs to support
ubuntu-xenial and ubuntu-bonic, which requires different elasticsearch
server versions. In addition, the programming interface of elastic
search server varies greatly before and after 5.0.0, which requires
different code of freezer-api to support. Pre-5.0.0 version
of elasticsearch server cannot be installed on ubuntu-bonic.
For the convenience of modification, freezer-api maintains
the elastic search.sh script by itself.

Change-Id: Ie069e2fd1e29daf53d8b1490f152cd820df036fe

subject: Deprecated error method
messages:
[{'account_id': 25740, 'date': '2018-01-29 09:14:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-01-30 02:14:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

thanks for having interests for this topic.
this change needs tests. we use horizon's test mock for api services, but horizon doesn't seems to have plan to support xstatic-angular to 1.6 or higher, including test mock, for now.
if you or someone have proposed patch to bump xstatic-angular, please add Depends-On line in commit message."}, {'account_id': 25740, 'date': '2018-01-30 03:02:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The problem was that .error method is not chainable because it ignore return value. This caused problems for people familiar with chaining and encouraged poor code from people unfamiliar with chaining.

To quote one of the AngularJS team:

IMO .success and .error were a bad bit of API design in the first place. This issue highlights a number of situations where developers get confused because they either expect .success and .error to work the same way as .then or vice versa. In a perfect world I would rather just ditch these $http specific "promises". Instead we could encourage developers to use the standard $q promise API .then and .catch. There is very little benefit IMO in working with explicit parameters over working with the response object.

— AngularJS Issue #10508  $http .success/.error dissimilar from how .then works.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-12-21 00:32:47.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Horizon team doesn't have plan to support angular 1.6 or higher."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-29 09:14:40.000000000', 'message': "Deprecated error method

$http's deprecated custom callback method: .error()
has been removed in AngularJS 1.6. Use the standard
.catch() promise method instead.

Change-Id: I168e69a5ba5f3beb67e71a596391d41bedfe53d9
"}]
commit_message:
Deprecated error method

$http's deprecated custom callback method: .error()
has been removed in AngularJS 1.6. Use the standard
.catch() promise method instead.

Change-Id: I168e69a5ba5f3beb67e71a596391d41bedfe53d9

method instead.

Change-Id: I1ce8402b0672712c275983ece0e5563d7ee52db0
"}]
commit_message:
Deprecated error method

$http's deprecated custom callback method: .error() has been
removed in AngularJS 1.6. Use the standard .catch() promise
method instead.

Change-Id: I1ce8402b0672712c275983ece0e5563d7ee52db0

commit_message:
Fence options before casting to json

These options could be "undefined" which is an object and not json
serializable. This change ensures if an option is undefined it defaults
to an empty set which will allow the option to be json serialized.

Change-Id: I1a81bafa441aa6400bfbec50d57e56df4d09bda3
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

  creating its connection.  Mocking the details of the session object
  and its uses proves too difficult, so I decided to remove it for now.

commit_message:
Fix missing auth_url when create senlinclient

- Use keystone session to create openstacksdk connection.
- Removed test case for getting senlin client because we are now passing
  in a session.  openstacksdk will try to use the session object when
  creating its connection.  Mocking the details of the session object
  and its uses proves too difficult, so I decided to remove it for now.

Change-Id: I11527b457ee04a38542894863da32b03aa67e790
Closes-Bug: #1805740
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/624528

commit_message:
conf: Convert 'live_migration_inbound_addr' to HostAddressOpt

Let's make use of oslo.config's build-in validation to protect operators
from some types of silly typos.

Change-Id: I155671d6e0528293326cffba32c7fe96a2ae37a2

subject: Add failover an amphora client support
messages:
[{'account_id': 25058, 'date': '2018-01-10 06:36:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-01-10 11:23:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Add release note: https://docs.openstack.org/reno/latest/user/usage.html'}, {'account_id': 25058, 'date': '2018-01-11 04:29:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25058, 'date': '2018-01-11 04:33:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Add release note: https://docs.openstack.org/reno/latest/user/usage.html

Thanks your review,I have modified it.'}, {'account_id': 25058, 'date': '2018-01-12 09:25:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27303, 'date': '2018-01-12 22:25:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

thanks for adding the requested tests'}, {'account_id': 25058, 'date': '2018-01-15 06:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 25058, 'date': '2018-01-15 06:57:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 25058, 'date': '2018-01-15 07:49:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 10850, 'date': '2018-01-15 23:07:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Though I am in general supportive of adding our octavia specific commands to the OpenStack client I am not sure if we should because if every vendor starts adding their own commands this will become confusing. So I can see a few options:

1) We have a special Octavia provider extension to the OpenStack client and other vendors are three to add their own extensions...
2) We make clear that it's an octavia provider functions by calling it OCTAVIA loadbalancer amphora failover or so
3) We have some sort of compatibility matrix and give good errors/decriptions, e.g. this functionality is only supported for the Octavia provider... 

Let's take this up in one of our meetings..."}, {'account_id': 27303, 'date': '2018-01-16 11:58:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Please make sure to get the API tests (for LIST/SHOW) merged either way.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-02-05 18:54:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I believe voting results were for:
`openstack octavia amphora failover`
So, we would need to register our own extension, which may mean the politics of making sure we're allowed to do that with OSC. My guess is we can bring this up and get a consensus in Dublin."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-12-11 10:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-12-20 21:15:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-12-20 21:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10850, 'date': '2018-12-20 23:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2

guess we settled on loadbalancer amphora failover'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-12-20 23:08:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

There was discordance among reviewers a while back. Today on IRC we seem to have agreed to the proposed command.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-12-20 23:16:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Yep, we did agree that precedent unfortunately outweighs the result of the vote we did. <_<'}]

commit_message:
Convert requests response from byte to string

In python 3 byte objects are no longer treated as strings.  Requests
responses can potentially be of type byte.  In that case the response
needs to be converted to string.

Change-Id: Id6959c3e4383281202afb3652afbb5220c39e5e4

commit_message:
WIP: Add featureset extra_args at rdo jobs

We found that rdo jobs were not using featursets extra_args, meaning
stuff like not using podman at oc, this try to append that.

Closes-Bug: #1809280
Change-Id: I272aa4dadef3b282d0add78dface4eaf429e5530

(cherry picked from commit 3562f380493bcea4b98d8da11a1718250b2bda6b)

'}]
commit_message:
Bump libvirt-python requirement to 4.6.0

libvirt-python 4.4.0 fails to build on CentOS 7.6 with
libvirt-4.5.0-10.el7_6.3 and libvirt-devel-4.5.0-10.el_7_6.3.

Bump the requirement to 4.6.0 since 4.5.0 failed testing.

Change-Id: I9c3110de0eedc1982c4e8c5af3a8682cd3bad72a
(cherry picked from commit 3562f380493bcea4b98d8da11a1718250b2bda6b)
(cherry picked from commit ef170e7ab54144390ad8fe746deef7f9de8bb1a1)
(cherry picked from commit 53fc7fcabc013444099efa3ca33d611f0b6fb68f)

commit_message:
Keystone podSecurityContext

securitycontext with non-root user is implemented at pod level
and leveraged the helm-toolkit snippet

Fix for adding allowPrivilegeEscalation flag as a blanket
policy on the pod in the keyston chart

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-22 02:08:21.000000000', 'message': "Allow skip processing exposed ports

The interface 'network_driver_program_external_connectivity' will
dynamically create security group and security group rules to open
the ports exposed by the container. However, these methods are
very heavy and significantly slow down the container start/stop.

However, such features (dynamically configure SGs) are not mandatory.
Users can manually configure the SGs at create-time or runtime.
This patch make the processing of exposed ports configurable.
As a result, it can be disabled if users want to manually manage
the SGs.

Change-Id: I6d6d176512e6b30bb7372408aec1a7bac12335ab

commit_message:
Allow skip processing exposed ports

The endpoints 'network_driver_program_external_connectivity'
and 'network_driver_revoke_external_connectivity' will dynamically
create security group and security group rules to open the ports
exposed by the docker container. However, such processing invokes
too much neutron API calls thus significantly slowing down the
container start/stop. However, such processing is not mandatory
because users can manually configure the SGs to achieve the
equivalent.

This patch make the processing of exposed ports configurable.
As a result, it can be disabled if users want a better performance.

Change-Id: I6d6d176512e6b30bb7372408aec1a7bac12335ab

commit_message:
Increase LXC container shutdown delay

Increasing default shutdown delay before containers are force-killed.  Short default has resulted in corruption of Galera db on controller reboots

Change-Id: I5f3ce0ac01bf1eecb28eba89536384fc895176e0
Related-Bug: 1806696

[{'created': '2018-12-19 11:08:37.000000000', 'message': 'Make sure we do not match multiple remotes when waiting for them

The current grep could match node-1 even when we're waiting for node-11.
Add a space so we're sure that we match only the right node:
[root@controller-0 ~]# pcs status |grep -e "overcloud-novacomputeiha-1\s.*Started"
 overcloud-novacomputeiha-1     (ocf::pacemaker:remote):        Started controller-1
[root@controller-0 ~]# pcs status |grep -e "overcloud-novacomputeiha-11\s.*Started"
 overcloud-novacomputeiha-11    (ocf::pacemaker:remote):        Started controller-0

Change-Id: Ieedf6020f78015a9fe19f8ae61e0e6e4a3b4cb5b
Related-Bug: #1807906
(cherry picked from commit ce6df5888ddadcb6cfeed1db588b03cbf3fc103c)
'}]
commit_message:
Make sure we do not match multiple remotes when waiting for them

The current grep could match node-1 even when we're waiting for node-11.
Add a space so we're sure that we match only the right node:
[root@controller-0 ~]# pcs status |grep -e "overcloud-novacomputeiha-1\s.*Started"
 overcloud-novacomputeiha-1     (ocf::pacemaker:remote):        Started controller-1
[root@controller-0 ~]# pcs status |grep -e "overcloud-novacomputeiha-11\s.*Started"
 overcloud-novacomputeiha-11    (ocf::pacemaker:remote):        Started controller-0

Change-Id: Ieedf6020f78015a9fe19f8ae61e0e6e4a3b4cb5b
Related-Bug: #1807906
(cherry picked from commit ce6df5888ddadcb6cfeed1db588b03cbf3fc103c)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-19 04:04:44.000000000', 'message': "Fix name of 'integrated-gate-py35' project template

Project template 'integrated-gate-py35' was added when OpenStack gate
used to run on xenial distro where python 3.5 is available.

Now we have migrated the gate to Bionic where python 3.6 is available.
With that migration, gate jobs in 'integrated-gate-py35' template are
running on python 3.6 not on 3.5 which makes this template name confusing.

This commit rename 'integrated-gate-py35' to 'integrated-gate-py3'
so that it can convey that template will use available python 3 version
present in used distro.

Renaming the template cannot be done directly as old template name is used in many
project repo and their stable branches. We need to provide new template
'integrated-gate-py3' and once all project will switch to this new
template then, we can remove the old 'integrated-gate-py35' template.

Change-Id: I050a0f81d6f5c00fffa05954ee740840c2a62eff
"}]
commit_message:
Fix name of 'integrated-gate-py35' project template

Project template 'integrated-gate-py35' was added when OpenStack gate
used to run on xenial distro where python 3.5 is available.

Now we have migrated the gate to Bionic where python 3.6 is available.
With that migration, gate jobs in 'integrated-gate-py35' template are
running on python 3.6 not on 3.5 which makes this template name confusing.

This commit rename 'integrated-gate-py35' to 'integrated-gate-py3'
so that it can convey that template will use available python 3 version
present in used distro.

Renaming the template cannot be done directly as old template name is used in many
project repo and their stable branches. We need to provide new template
'integrated-gate-py3' and once all project will switch to this new
template then, we can remove the old 'integrated-gate-py35' template.

Change-Id: I050a0f81d6f5c00fffa05954ee740840c2a62eff

commit_message:
Handle unbound vif plug errors on compute restart

As with change Ia963a093a1b26d90b4de2e8fc623031cf175aece, we can
sometimes cache failed port binding information which we'll see on
startup. Long term, the fix for both issues is to figure out how this is
being cached and stop that happening but for now we simply need to allow
the service to start up.

To this end, we copy the approach in the aforementioned change and
implement a translation function in os_vif_util for unbound which
will make the plug_vifs code raise VirtualInterfacePlugException which
is what the _init_instance code in ComputeManager is already handling.

This has the same caveats as that change, namely that there may be
smarter ways to do this that we should explore. However, that change
also included a note which goes someway to explaining this.

Change-Id: Iaec1f6fd12dba8b11991b7a7595593d5c8b1db50
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Related-bug: #1784579
Closes-bug: #1809136
(cherry picked from commit 1def76a1c49032d93ab6c7ee61dbbfe8e29cafca)

commit_message:
Add osc repo to the base job definition

The osc-functional-devstack job is to be run against devstack changes in
order to verify that the devstack-tox-functional job, which our job is
based upon, doesn't introduce a regression[0]. In order to prevent this
from failing, include our own repo as required-project.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/526115

Change-Id: I782cd51dda1477c2e3a067cd902a3d3f29490083

subject: Fix fact gathering with --limit
messages: [{'account_id': 19930, 'date': '2018-12-20 09:04:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-20 09:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 27781, 'date': '2018-12-20 14:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23717, 'date': '2018-12-20 16:29:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-20 09:04:18.000000000', 'message': 'Fix fact gathering with --limit

Prior to this change, when the --limit argument is used, each host in the
limit gathers facts for every other host. This is clearly unnecessary, and
can result in up to (N-1)^2 fact gathers.

This change gathers facts for each host only once. Hosts that are not in
the limit are divided between those that are in the limit, and facts are
gathered via delegation.

This change also factors out the fact gathering logic into a separate
playbook that is imported where necessary.

Change-Id: I923df5af41a7f1b7b0142d0da185a9a0979be543
(cherry picked from commit 56b4352f9edd23c38bb24ff6eaec6748858e3e9f)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix fact gathering with --limit

Prior to this change, when the --limit argument is used, each host in the
limit gathers facts for every other host. This is clearly unnecessary, and
can result in up to (N-1)^2 fact gathers.

This change gathers facts for each host only once. Hosts that are not in
the limit are divided between those that are in the limit, and facts are
gathered via delegation.

This change also factors out the fact gathering logic into a separate
playbook that is imported where necessary.

Change-Id: I923df5af41a7f1b7b0142d0da185a9a0979be543
(cherry picked from commit 56b4352f9edd23c38bb24ff6eaec6748858e3e9f)

commit_message:
Ensure lb sg rules are not updated without namespaces

This patch ensures Octavia LoadBalancer SG rules are not updated
by the lbaas driver when the namespace isolation feature is not
enabled.

Closes-Bug: 1809119
Change-Id: I09af490e77fcb722115e75147d5d004b2f4e6426

commit_message:
Stop cleaning images to be deleted in remotefs driver

Add '-d' flag to qemu-img commit operations during
snapshot deletion in remotefs driver.

Change-Id: I66396fb7e2616be734b7c8f73b87c650b1e603bf
Closes-Bug: #1805853
(cherry picked from commit 13499f58959ddc78f00e11cc8478fe40c95ed112)

[{'created': '2018-12-17 20:21:40.000000000', 'message': "Remove legacy RequestSpec compat from conductor rebuild_instance

Change I34ffaf285718059b55f90e812b57f1e11d566c6f made the
RequestSpec lookup required in the API, so we should not get
to conductor's rebuild_instance() method without a request spec

Change-Id: I0a8c18df7ef060647e822e81064d4c663166db8f
"}, {'created': '2018-12-18 16:14:11.000000000', 'message': "Remove legacy RequestSpec compat from conductor rebuild_instance

Change I34ffaf285718059b55f90e812b57f1e11d566c6f made the
RequestSpec lookup required in the API, so we should not get
to conductor's rebuild_instance() method without a request spec

Change-Id: I0a8c18df7ef060647e822e81064d4c663166db8f

commit_message:
Remove legacy RequestSpec compat from conductor rebuild_instance

Change I34ffaf285718059b55f90e812b57f1e11d566c6f made the
RequestSpec lookup required in the API, so we should not get
to conductor's rebuild_instance() method without a request spec
so this change removes the compat code from that method.

Related to blueprint request-spec-use-by-compute

Change-Id: I0a8c18df7ef060647e822e81064d4c663166db8f

commit_message:
Remove legacy RequestSpec compat from conductor unshelve_instance

Change I34ffaf285718059b55f90e812b57f1e11d566c6f made the
RequestSpec lookup required in the API, so we should not get
to conductor's unshelve_instance() method without a request spec
so this change removes the compat code from that method.

Related to blueprint request-spec-use-by-compute

Change-Id: Ib2b9fb728b92ba3dbefe0a2eb7a9f04035758735

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be

commit_message:
Support list of controller ip for the amphorae heartbeat receiver

In multi controller deployment, kolla will generate
"controller_ip_port_list option" in [health_manager] section with
ONLY IP of that node instead of a list of controller ip.
Therefor, "amphora-agent.conf" file of amphora instance will
contain IP of ONLY ONE controller node.
In case of that node fail, amphora agent won't send heartbeat
message to other health manager node, and the loadbalancer will
go to ERROR state.

Change-Id: I102ed6ba3fff2c12cc6d37f81ad59508eacc859c
Co-Authored-By: Hieu LE <hieulq2@viettel.com.vn>

[{'created': '2018-12-14 12:08:03.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Create cells before starting nova services

Nova services may reasonably expect cell databases to exist when they
start. The current cell setup tasks in kolla run after the nova
containers have started, meaning that cells may not exist in the
database when they start. In particular, we are seeing issues in kolla
CI currently with jobs timing out waiting for nova compute services to
start. The following error is seen in the nova logs of these jobs, which
may or may not be relevant:

No cells are configured, unable to continue

This change creates the cell0 and cell1 databases prior to starting nova
services.

Change-Id: I2c1e991064f9f588f398ccbabda94f69dc285e61

No cells are configured, unable to continue

services.

In order to do this, we must create new containers in which to run the
nova-manage commands, because the nova-api container may not yet exist.

We also add the standard output and error to the module's result when a
non-detached container is run. A secondary benefit of this is that the
output of bootstrap containers is now displayed in the Ansible output if

commit_message:
Create cells before starting nova services

Nova services may reasonably expect cell databases to exist when they
start. The current cell setup tasks in kolla run after the nova
containers have started, meaning that cells may or may not exist in the
database when they start, depending on timing. In particular, we are
seeing issues in kolla CI currently with jobs timing out waiting for
nova compute services to start. The following error is seen in the nova
logs of these jobs, which may or may not be relevant:

No cells are configured, unable to continue

This change creates the cell0 and cell1 databases prior to starting nova
services.

In order to do this, we must create new containers in which to run the
nova-manage commands, because the nova-api container may not yet exist.
This required adding support to the kolla_docker module for specifying a
command for the container to run that overrides the image's command.

We also add the standard output and error to the module's result when a
non-detached container is run. A secondary benefit of this is that the
output of bootstrap containers is now displayed in the Ansible output if
the bootstrapping command fails, which will help with debugging.

Change-Id: I2c1e991064f9f588f398ccbabda94f69dc285e61
Closes-Bug: #1808575

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-19 23:20:27.000000000', 'message': "Update port device_owner when unshelving

When we shelve offload an instance, we unplug VIFs, delete
the guest from the compute host, etc. The instance is still
logically attached to its ports but they aren't connected
on any host.

When we unshelve an instance, it is scheduled and created
on a potentially new host, in a potentially new availability
zone. During unshelve, the compute manager will call the
setup_instance_network_on_host() method to update the port
host binding information for the new host, but was not
updating the device_owner, which reflects the availability
zone that the instance is in. Because of this, an instance
can be created in az1, shelved, and then unshelved in az2
but the port device_owner still says az1 even though the
port host binding is for a compute host in az2.

This change simply updates the port device_owner when
updating the port binding host during unshelve.

A TODO is left in the cleanup_instance_network_on_host()
method which is called during shelve offload but is currently
not implemented. We should unbind ports when shelve offloading,
but that is a bit of a bigger change and left for a separate
patch since it is not technically needed for this bug fix.

Change-Id: Ibd1cbe0e9b5cf3ede542dbf62b1a7d503ba7ea06
Closes-Bug: #1759924
(cherry picked from commit 93802619adde69bf84d26d7231480abb4da07c91)
"}]
commit_message:
Update port device_owner when unshelving

When we shelve offload an instance, we unplug VIFs, delete
the guest from the compute host, etc. The instance is still
logically attached to its ports but they aren't connected
on any host.

When we unshelve an instance, it is scheduled and created
on a potentially new host, in a potentially new availability
zone. During unshelve, the compute manager will call the
setup_instance_network_on_host() method to update the port
host binding information for the new host, but was not
updating the device_owner, which reflects the availability
zone that the instance is in. Because of this, an instance
can be created in az1, shelved, and then unshelved in az2
but the port device_owner still says az1 even though the
port host binding is for a compute host in az2.

This change simply updates the port device_owner when
updating the port binding host during unshelve.

A TODO is left in the cleanup_instance_network_on_host()
method which is called during shelve offload but is currently
not implemented. We should unbind ports when shelve offloading,
but that is a bit of a bigger change and left for a separate
patch since it is not technically needed for this bug fix.

Change-Id: Ibd1cbe0e9b5cf3ede542dbf62b1a7d503ba7ea06
Closes-Bug: #1759924
(cherry picked from commit 93802619adde69bf84d26d7231480abb4da07c91)

commit_message:
[CEPH] Support a troubleshooting option to reset PG metadata

Ceph upstream bug: https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/21142 is
impacting the availability of our sites in pipeline. Add an option
to reset the past interval metadata time on an OSDs PG to solve for
this issue if it occurs.

Change-Id: I1fe0bee6ce8aa402c241f1ad457bbf532945a530

commit_message:
Update show_multiple_locations deprecation note

Update logged text to indicate our intentions with respect
to the show_multiple_locations configuration option, which
has been deprecated since Newton and advertised as subject
to removal in Pike.  Also correct the misleading impression
in the deprecation notice and earlier release notes that
functionality that requires show_multiple_locations = True
can be configured via policies at the current time.  Also
adds a release note to this effect.

Change-Id: I5bf0c8af9dfe87e0d17f7a16d4676f387b4379f6
Closes-bug: #1808375

commit_message:
Added create and update hooks to version mixin

Objects using the version mixin will now have the version automatically
added or updated in the create and update hooks respectively.

Change-Id: I198eb89b45f0f16abb97611b8e43c106e24b9b49
Closes-Bug: #1808331
Co-Authored-By: Omer Anson <omer.anson@toganetworks.com>

Otherwise, Keepalived tries to execute its scripts as
`keepalived_script`, which doesn't exist, so none of the scripts get
executed at all. On top of that, some of the scripts require root

commit_message:
Set Keepalived script_user to root

Otherwise, Keepalived tries to execute its scripts as
`keepalived_script`, which doesn't exist, so none of the scripts get
executed at all. On top of that, some of the scripts require root
privileges, so `script_user` needs to be set to `root`.

Change-Id: Ia5cc0154cf520132d133679b64fc5f5c698dce85
Closes-Bug: 1806004

commit_message:
Update the systemd-nspawn template for legacy systemd environments

The systemd-nspawn template has been updated to better support for
modern systems. This was primarily done for better centos and suse
support which have older versions of systemd.

Change-Id: I4c01102dae8445317a3a891861f2cd4bef20492b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

Run get_all just after init finishes, without the initial wait for
 snapshot_interval seconds.

subject: Correct failure when stopping cluster state is ignored
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-12-20 14:06:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-12-20 14:57:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-12-20 15:32:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-20 14:06:35.000000000', 'message': 'Correct failure when stopping cluster state is ignored

If the user passes in the `galera_ignore_cluster_state=true` flag, like
in the case of a node addition or a rolling replacement of nodes,
this role will fail to execute on all new nodes due to the existance of
a functioning cluster galera cluster. The first task in the pre-upgrade
steps attempts to stop the mysql service prior to running anything else.

In this patch we change the task flow to evaluate whether a service
exists, and if it does then to stop it - otherwise skip that task. This
ensures that if `galera_ignore_cluster_state=true` is passed through, the
playbook will run successfully.

Backport note:
This is a combined backport of https://review.openstack.org/607071 and
https://review.openstack.org/625929

Change-Id: Ib26c807057b9114e02ad32c759a5028555788363
(cherry picked from commit 69e2c736a07edc24ed1335bbf4d1a554a39fc40d)
'}]
commit_message:
Correct failure when stopping cluster state is ignored

If the user passes in the `galera_ignore_cluster_state=true` flag, like
in the case of a node addition or a rolling replacement of nodes,
this role will fail to execute on all new nodes due to the existance of
a functioning cluster galera cluster. The first task in the pre-upgrade
steps attempts to stop the mysql service prior to running anything else.

In this patch we change the task flow to evaluate whether a service
exists, and if it does then to stop it - otherwise skip that task. This
ensures that if `galera_ignore_cluster_state=true` is passed through, the
playbook will run successfully.

Backport note:
This is a combined backport of https://review.openstack.org/607071 and
https://review.openstack.org/625929

Change-Id: Ib26c807057b9114e02ad32c759a5028555788363
(cherry picked from commit 69e2c736a07edc24ed1335bbf4d1a554a39fc40d)

subject: Fix discrepancy between action and workflow update/delete
messages:
[{'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2017-06-22 13:23:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2017-06-22 14:01:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This breaks sync_db since the actions (unlike workflows) are updated and not wiped out. And now that the update requires the application context, it complains that it can't be found.

Should we change the behavior of sync_db or add a fake application context?"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-06-22 14:10:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-mistral-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-docs-ubuntu-xenial/b1d7360//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 46s
- gate-mistral-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/4d788ba/ : FAILURE in 5m 27s

- gate-mistral-python35 http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-python35/a84dc02/ : FAILURE in 4m 40s
- mistral-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/mistral-coverage-ubuntu-xenial-nv/a2ab677/ : FAILURE in 6m 48s (non-voting)
- gate-rally-dsvm-mistral-task-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-rally-dsvm-mistral-task-ubuntu-xenial-nv/806c43d/ : SUCCESS in 45m 23s (non-voting)
- gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-ubuntu-xenial-nv/9b1e877/ : FAILURE in 25m 10s (non-voting)
- gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-non-apache-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-non-apache-ubuntu-xenial-nv/7d2f67d/ : FAILURE in 25m 35s (non-voting)
- gate-mistral-tox-unit-mysql-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-tox-unit-mysql-ubuntu-xenial/2db4637/ : FAILURE in 3m 35s (non-voting)
- gate-mistral-tox-unit-postgresql-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-tox-unit-postgresql-ubuntu-xenial/cdcb5da/ : FAILURE in 4m 07s (non-voting)
- gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario003-multinode-oooq-puppet http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario003-multinode-oooq-puppet/010748b/ : FAILURE in 33m 48s
- gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-kombu-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/14/476514/1/check/gate-mistral-devstack-dsvm-kombu-ubuntu-xenial-nv/5175459/ : FAILURE in 34m 27s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 03:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2018-02-21 09:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2018-02-21 09:49:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Needs tests to make sure we don't get a regression here later"}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-02-21 09:59:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sure, it's just that I don't have much time to work on Mistral right now. I'll do it when I've nothing to do some week end."}, {'account_id': 11391, 'date': '2018-03-13 16:29:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-03-14 08:11:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

This change request is quite old; it might be irrelevant for the master branch right now. The reason for implementing this is to make sure that only owners could delete/edit their actions and not those of others (just like for workflows).'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-11 22:59:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-12 22:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-13 08:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-13 08:15:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Uploaded patch set 5.

The tests should work. It was complaining about the fact that a non-admin user should not be able to modify a system action, which is legit and which is now detected thanks to this change request.

You can start reviewing but I'm not done as I need to add some tests (similar to what has been done for workflow definitions) to test the different test cases."}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-13 08:30:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > Uploaded patch set 5.
 > 
 > The tests should work. It was complaining about the fact that a
 > non-admin user should not be able to modify a system action, which
 > is legit and which is now detected thanks to this change request.
 > 
 > You can start reviewing but I'm not done as I need to add some
 > tests (similar to what has been done for workflow definitions) to
 > test the different test cases.

As for why it does not work in my case with policies, it's because I don't use Keystone, so there is no authentication context (whether I use a custom authentication mechanism or none).

The problem is that this discrepancy makes it possible to edit system actions as non-admin (when it is not possible for workflows). It is also true of actions with a non-default project id."}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2018-12-13 12:37:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-13 18:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)

That's a security update which is why you can't see it. If a non-admin user can delete/modify ad-hoc actions the admin created, this can be dangerous. This happens only if Keystone is not used to authenticate the user.

I will fix the typo in the word "decrepancy" and add some tests in the next patch set.'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-13 22:01:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-13 22:03:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

Ready for reviews'}, {'account_id': 18955, 'date': '2018-12-20 07:09:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Not sure why this fix in db side. As policy is already there.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/mistral/tree/master/mistral/policies'}, {'account_id': 22003, 'date': '2018-12-20 15:59:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Not sure why this fix in db side. As policy is already there.
 > 
 > [1]: https://github.com/openstack/mistral/tree/master/mistral/policies

I don't use Keystone, so there is no authentication context (whether I use a custom authentication mechanism or none).

The problem is that this discrepancy makes it possible to edit system actions as non-admin (when it is not possible for workflows). It is also true of actions with a non-default project id.

There are 3 ways around this problem:
- make it possible to have a complete authentication and access system without Keystone (any custom auth). That's the long term fix, but it will require much more work than this.
- remove the checks for workflows, if they should not be there for actions, then it should be the same for workflows. The problem is that it will enable users who do not use Keystone to edit workflows pushed by default.
- this way: this is a short-term fix but it fixes both an inconsistency in the code and a security issue (since without Keystone, users can edit actions that were push by the sync script)"}]

commit_message:
Fix discrepancy between action and workflow update/delete

The owner of the action was not checked when
updating or deleting an action. This makes it
possible to edit the action when the
authentication is on but is not keystone.

Change-Id: Ie8547ce0eac9d7568db8fa3a7feb7ceebceffd3e
Closes-Bug: #1699786

commit_message:
Deprecate the ThreadGroup.cancel() API

This API is awkward, inefficient, incoherent, and unintuitive. The bug
fix for which it was originally added was abandoned in favour of a
different approach, so it was never used. It appears that no consumers
are currently calling it. It would be best if none started.

Add a deprecation warning to discourage its use and allow us to remove
it altogether at some point in the future.

Change-Id: I9559c7051024019fac957385faced645920b815c

commit_message:
Changes to support standalone ironic

For standalone ironic deployments, such as those deployed using bifrost, there
is typically no keystone or placement service running. Use of the ironic API is
without authentication. We use clouds.yaml in this case.

Change-Id: I61ed791d019e43f6dfc632fa185f079b385c290c
Story: 2004425
Task: 28077

commit_message:
Fix ansible stable pin in tox test

We want to use the latest version from the stable-2.5 branch, not pin to
2.5.0 which has some issues that break our tests.

Change-Id: If7bab97191c5a29bac79e3f3ecaf10bfe0eac6b5

commit_message:
InstanceInfo: store more runtime information of instance

libvirt.virDomain.info have more runtime information,
such as cpu and memory.
This patch store all info from virDomain.info into InstanceInfo,
and remove all callings of _get_domain_info.

Change-Id: I8ad7bf2bef7e48bc3524f9922f0f630183d8487b
Signed-off-by: Chen Hanxiao <chenhx@certusnet.com.cn>

commit_message:
Support legacy drivers

Adds support for pxe_ipmitool, pxe_ipmitool_socat, agent_ipmitool and
agent_ipmitool_socat drivers with virtualbmc. Also adds entries for SNMP-based
drivers.

Change-Id: I461e74e3199e02a35ee0d3ddc1f6e49c1eda0536

[{'created': '2018-12-18 16:35:04.000000000', 'message': 'Support ocata release of ironic

In the Ocata release, the physical_network field of ports did not exist.
The safest thing to do is to simply ignore it in this case.

It is also possible for the local_link_connection fields to not have switch_id,
switch_info or port_id attributes, so we now use .get(attr) to avoid an
attribute lookup error.

Change-Id: Ib4829dbd89fcedc121f493d6af76702421b399f7
TrivialFix

commit_message:
Support ocata release of ironic

In the Ocata release, the physical_network field of ports did not exist.
The safest thing to do is to simply ignore it in this case.

It is also possible for the local_link_connection fields to not have switch_id,
switch_info or port_id attributes, so we now use .get(attr) to avoid an
attribute lookup error.

Change-Id: Ib4829dbd89fcedc121f493d6af76702421b399f7
TrivialFix

commit_message:
Pin neutron SHA until migrations output is fixed

In I20327bd1d5f784e021e9e1f1cbba1ef654271bfb a change of the
output interface was implemented in neutron which breaks our
checks for whether there are any migrations outstanding.

Until https://review.openstack.org/626565 is merged or an
alternative fix is implemented, we pin the neutron SHA for
role tests.

Change-Id: I1f2d765c416773e3fad314dcde1907ef9f1fe227

commit_message:
Start using direct REST in normalize tests

This is too synthetic and we're missing things. Switch to requests_mock.

In doing this, remove the extra creation of extra connection objects in
the base test. Reorganize the normalize test file so that they just drop
in a strict_cloud flag and get the cloud created properly the first
time.

Change-Id: I86436b439cbc4b236b806af7eed195b198ce54e8

(4 comments)

looks good and straight forward but please remove 'extensions' bits as there are no extensions actually."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2017-03-06 17:11:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Should we do nic tags in the same microversion? It seems weirdly inconsistent that you can set tags on nics and bdms but can only get tags (via the API, the metadata service is something else) on bdms.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2017-03-07 01:13:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

> Should we do nic tags in the same microversion? It seems weirdly
> inconsistent that you can set tags on nics and bdms but can only get
> tags (via the API, the metadata service is something else) on bdms.

The virtual interfaces is only implemented for nova-network [1]. Internally, the virtual_interfaces database table used to be only for nova-network, but as of 2.32 we use if for Neutron as well, to store nic tags. So it'd be conceivable to add tags to bdms, and in the same microversion make os-virtual-interfaces start returning stuff for Neutron as well. I'm not sure it's a good idea, so I'll remove my -1 from this spec, but it's something to think about.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=list-virtual-interfaces-detail,list-port-interfaces-detail#list-virtual-interfaces"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2017-03-07 06:39:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Agree with Gmann about not talking "extension"'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2017-03-10 15:45:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

(5 comments)

Artom, I think you asked about this in IRC once (I thought it was actually discussed in the spec earlier).

I left nic tags out because of some trickiness with the os-virtual-interfaces and os-interfaces APIs. In I think Newton Alex had a spec that proposed deprecating one of those APIs since it was a proxy to Neutron, but I'm not clear on the path forward there.

I think it was this:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/384261/

Oh, and I had this:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/350277/

But John didn't like that, so basically the future of the various virtual interface APIs in nova are unclear which is why I left it out here.

Maybe the right thing to do is make this dependent on sorting out the interface APIs."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2017-03-10 16:12:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

You're proposing modifying the os-volume_attachment API to include tags in the GET response. Since we're going to have tagged attach in the os-volume_attachment API with the tagged attach path series (hopefully in Pike), we could use that as inspiration and, in the same way that tagged attach also adds tags to os-interface POST, we can add tags to os-interface GET in the same microversion as tags in os-volume_attachments GET.

The only issue I see with that is that I don't think this will include nova-network interfaces. Not sure how much of a problem that is though."}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2017-04-04 13:28:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2017-04-04 22:47:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2017-04-07 01:41:42.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'm going to drop this for Pike. I think the first step in getting here is deprecating the os-virtual-interface API and replacing that with the os-interface API. Then we can do a microversion after that to return both bdm and vif tags."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-26 19:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

Going to restore this and rewrite it to be more generic for just exposing volume attachment (bdm) and attached port (virtual interface) device tags.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-26 21:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-26 21:29:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2018-10-27 00:43:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Straighforward spec, issue with extra DB query when showing interface tags was covered, I can't think of other potential pain points. -1 is for inline L178 and L238, the rest are just musings."}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2018-10-27 00:45:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Never mind me, we're good."}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-10-29 08:48:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-29 13:59:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2018-11-08 11:11:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-09 14:24:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-19 14:31:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2018-11-19 14:53:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2018-12-03 08:06:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-12-03 19:12:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-03 19:28:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2018-12-03 19:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-12-03 19:39:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Sounds like I'm OK to leave this as written:

(1:37:32 PM) dansmith: mriedem: note that pulling it from an api node via instance_extra is the same number of hits to the db as just doing an query for all the virtual_interfaces for the instance presumptively, since the api is hitting the db directly"}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2018-12-20 14:44:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(4 comments)

While there are still some implementation details to be verified, I'm fine with accepting this spec now and see later how it goes."}]

commit_message:
Expose virtual device tags in REST API

The 2.32 microversion allows creating a server with tagged block devices
and virtual interfaces (ports) and the 2.49 microversion allows specifying
a tag when attaching volumes and ports, but there is no way to get those
tags out of the REST API. This spec proposes to expose the block device
mapping and virtual interface tags in the REST API when listing volume
attachments and ports for a given server.

APIImpact

Spec for blueprint expose-virtual-device-tags-in-rest-api

Change-Id: I13a937d12269bfd496ca81f208cdf913bb62e311

commit_message:
Gate on kayobe overcloud deploy job

Until we have ironic jobs using tenks, gate on the kayobe overcloud deploy job,
which uses tenks to test bare metal compute provisioning.

Change-Id: I6c63f83550f53cc8624c1d938ba9c7450b7fcf27

[{'created': '2018-12-19 20:33:19.000000000', 'message': "Document using service user tokens for long running operations

A recent thread in the mailing list [1] reminded me that we
don't have any documentation for the service user token feature
added back in ocata under blueprint use-service-tokens.

This change adds a troubleshooting entry for when using service
user tokens would be useful, and links to it from two known
trouble spots: live migration timeouts and creating images.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/001130.html

Change-Id: I1dda889038ffe67d53ceb35049aa1f2a9da39ae8
Closes-Bug: #1809165
"}]
commit_message:
Document using service user tokens for long running operations

A recent thread in the mailing list [1] reminded me that we
don't have any documentation for the service user token feature
added back in ocata under blueprint use-service-tokens.

This change adds a troubleshooting entry for when using service
user tokens would be useful, and links to it from two known
trouble spots: live migration timeouts and creating images.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/001130.html

Change-Id: I1dda889038ffe67d53ceb35049aa1f2a9da39ae8
Closes-Bug: #1809165

commit_message:
Pre-cleanup migration resources and fix validation

This patch avoids the duplication/conflict of resources
(pre-migration and post-migration) if the migration was stopped
by an error and it's retried.

Also makes sure that a non-working validation will fail.

Change-Id: I5ce17e23ee52e936aeee78f64fb0df127816b1bd
Closes-Bug: #1804477

commit_message:
Only run the needed services for CephFS jobs

These jobs often fail due to timeouts so only enable the services
required for devstack tests with these back ends.

Change-Id: Ib620ec3c2a9999ea9908a7c23aa7172c40a4cbd9

commit_message:
pkg-map for fedora/python3

  * yum_plugin_priorities_package set to "" as it is part of DNF.
  * python packages in fedora start with python2/python3 naming

Change-Id: I1fed33e62a3d383c13de5f7c8d1f26473113801e

Convert usage of tgt-admin and tgtadm to use privsep rather than
the rootwrap wrapper.

Change-Id: Ibdb94fc3aebb01fee6e2e76adeaa5d34a4af8753
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move tgt targets to privsep

Convert usage of tgt-admin and tgtadm to use privsep rather than
the rootwrap wrapper.

Change-Id: Ibdb94fc3aebb01fee6e2e76adeaa5d34a4af8753
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2018-07-08 14:02:07.000000000', 'message': "correct port_security behavior when enabled/disabled

This change will address the following:
 * sync tempest port_security conf with neutron's default.
 * Correct behavior when port_security is False or extension
   not available, do not create port_security resources.

commit_message:
correct port_security behavior when enabled/disabled

This change will address the following:
 * sync tempest port_security conf with neutron's default.
 * Correct behavior when port_security is False or extension
   not available, do not create port_security resources.

Change-Id: Ic8f2b397f4cff01cfc53e9c14edf2a7d34e5b43f

Pike only fix.

Some versions of the openstack client output a warning when a version is not

Change-Id: I7c2f88cb78c564aaa88e8856fc7ad698050acd9b

commit_message:
Add ironic API version to overcloud hardware inspect

Pike only fix.

Some versions of the openstack client output a warning when a version is not
specified. This gets mixed up with the command's output, causing the parsing of
node states to fail. The 1.34 version is already used for overcloud
provisioning, so do the same for inspection.

Change-Id: I7c2f88cb78c564aaa88e8856fc7ad698050acd9b

messages:
[{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-12-18 14:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-18 15:50:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-12-18 16:17:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-18 17:05:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2018-12-20 12:38:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-18 14:38:35.000000000', 'message': 'When upgrading, only stop the service if it exists

In Id9c4f11b3536e7f9d510f5ef8e6d82a82a96adac we implemented a
failed_when condition to ignore the state of the service stop task
when `galera_ignore_cluster_state=true` is passed through.

Unfortunately, the omit filter does not work in a task context [1],
resulting in the task always failing because the omit placeholder
string is evaluated as true. This makes the task always fail when
running an upgrade.

In this patch we change the task flow to evaluate whether a service
exists, and if it does then to stop it - otherwise skip that task.
This should cater for the rolling replacement use-case and will
work in every other situation too.

[1] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/25678

Change-Id: Ib26c807057b9114e02ad32c759a5028555788363
'}]
commit_message:
When upgrading, only stop the service if it exists

In Id9c4f11b3536e7f9d510f5ef8e6d82a82a96adac we implemented a
failed_when condition to ignore the state of the service stop task
when `galera_ignore_cluster_state=true` is passed through.

Unfortunately, the omit filter does not work in a task context [1],
resulting in the task always failing because the omit placeholder
string is evaluated as true. This makes the task always fail when
running an upgrade.

In this patch we change the task flow to evaluate whether a service
exists, and if it does then to stop it - otherwise skip that task.
This should cater for the rolling replacement use-case and will
work in every other situation too.

[1] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/25678

Change-Id: Ib26c807057b9114e02ad32c759a5028555788363

commit_message:
Add container_id into VIFSriovDriver binding driver

Commit 0478a47502 which adds
container_id into connect/disconnect interface was merged
right before 4d53db2fdf "Add SR-IOV binding driver to CNI",
This and lack of unit test lead to inconsistency and run time
error. This commit fix this.

Also it adds unit tests for this case and minor fix for case
when we can accidentally return from VIFSriovDriver.connect before
._lock initialization.

Change-Id: I7fb50cd1dbd29b7be4dfbd7299b0013a9b9cafea
Signed-off-by: Alexey Perevalov <a.perevalov@samsung.com>

Change-Id: I20327bd1d5f784e021e9e1f1cbba1ef654271bfb
"}]
commit_message:
Log alembic migration script's output with oslo_log

Instead of using alembic.utils messages function which
prints output to stdout, lets use oslo_log logger to log
all such commands.
For logging error message alembic.utils module is still used
as those messages are quite important and should be displayed
to user in case of error.

This is needed to limit amount of output on stdout during
functional tests running on python3.5.

Change-Id: I20327bd1d5f784e021e9e1f1cbba1ef654271bfb

commit_message:
Define popular policy rules by constants (part 2)

This commit defines complex policy rules with constants.

Convenient functions policy_or and policy_and are introduced
so that complex policy rules can be defined easily.

Partially Implements: blueprint neutron-policy-in-code

Change-Id: Id56c787733f5bd016dab7adaf956d676dd358b82

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-19 16:16:37.000000000', 'message': "Handle unbound vif plug errors on compute restart

As with change Ia963a093a1b26d90b4de2e8fc623031cf175aece, we can
sometimes cache failed port binding information which we'll see on
startup. Long term, the fix for both issues is to figure out how this is
being cached and stop that happening but for now we simply need to allow
the service to start up.

To this end, we copy the approach in the aforementioned change and
implement a translation function in os_vif_util for binding_failed which
will make the plug_vifs code raise VirtualInterfacePlugException which
is what the _init_instance code in ComputeManager is already handling.

This has the same caveats as that change, namely that there may be
smarter ways to do this that we should explore. However, that change
also included a note which goes someway to explaining this.

Change-Id: Iaec1f6fd12dba8b11991b7a7595593d5c8b1db50
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Related-bug: #1784579
Closes-bug: #1809136

commit_message:
Handle unbound vif plug errors on compute restart

As with change Ia963a093a1b26d90b4de2e8fc623031cf175aece, we can
sometimes cache failed port binding information which we'll see on
startup. Long term, the fix for both issues is to figure out how this is
being cached and stop that happening but for now we simply need to allow
the service to start up.

To this end, we copy the approach in the aforementioned change and
implement a translation function in os_vif_util for unbound which
will make the plug_vifs code raise VirtualInterfacePlugException which
is what the _init_instance code in ComputeManager is already handling.

This has the same caveats as that change, namely that there may be
smarter ways to do this that we should explore. However, that change
also included a note which goes someway to explaining this.

Change-Id: Iaec1f6fd12dba8b11991b7a7595593d5c8b1db50
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Related-bug: #1784579
Closes-bug: #1809136

[{'created': '2018-11-27 08:14:52.000000000', 'message': "Windows SMBFS: fix using share subdirs

When using Scale-Out File Server SMB shares, we have to use the local
share paths instead of the UNC paths, if the host is part of the
cluster.

There's an os-win method that allows fetching the shared path, but
it expects the share name, while we're passing subdirs as well,
for which reason it fails.

We'll have to make sure we're passing the share name only, appending
the subdir afterwards.

Closes-Bug: #1805341

Change-Id: I47d7e7afefe050cd4b25435cfcfc3e8963bd04bc
"}, {'created': '2018-11-27 08:19:47.000000000', 'message': "Windows SMBFS: fix using share subdirs

When using Scale-Out File Server SMB shares, we have to use the local
share paths instead of the UNC paths if the host is part of the
cluster.

There's an os-win method that allows fetching the shared path but
it expects the share name, while we're passing subdirs as well,
for which reason it fails.

We'll have to make sure we're passing the share name only, appending
the subdir afterwards.

Closes-Bug: #1805341

Change-Id: I47d7e7afefe050cd4b25435cfcfc3e8963bd04bc
"}]
commit_message:
Windows SMBFS: fix using share subdirs

When using Scale-Out File Server SMB shares, we have to use the local
share paths instead of the UNC paths if the host is part of the
cluster.

There's an os-win method that allows fetching the shared path but
it expects the share name, while we're passing subdirs as well,
for which reason it fails.

We'll have to make sure we're passing the share name only, appending
the subdir afterwards.

Closes-Bug: #1805341

Change-Id: I47d7e7afefe050cd4b25435cfcfc3e8963bd04bc
